ParentCompanyName: Equilon Enterprises LLC dba Shell Oil Products US

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Fill shutoff device at 85% vessel capacity, Electrical classification
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Hydrocarbon detectors, temperature, pressure, and liquid level indicators

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Shell Oil Products US (Shell) - Nashville Terminal was constructed to comply with the National Fire Protection Association #58 (2004 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is this Facility's policy to adhere to all Federal, State, and Local codes/laws including updated versions of NFPA 58 to the extant feasible.  If an emergency were to occur, it is this Facility's policy to notify the Nashville Fire Department and the Davidson County LEPC, as appropriate, through the 911 service.  Medical emergencies will require notification of the Centennial, Baptist, Vanderbilt, and/or Saint Thomas Hospitals and associated ambulance service (Nashville-Davidson County Metro) via 911.  The Facility trains its employees to respond to small or initial stages of an emergency.



Shell - Nashville Terminal transfers/stores refined product (regular/premium gasoline and diesel fuel) and handles product additives, including the liquefied butane blending system (direct injection into refined product lines).  The Risk Management Program covers the butane blending system including the butane vessel, truck offloading station, and associated piping and appurtenances.



Shell - Nashville Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D - Program Level 3).  Additionally, this plan meets the requirements of the U.S. Department of Labor - Occupational Safety and Health Administration Process Safety Management regulations for Highly Hazardous Chemicals (29 CFR Part 1910.119) inclusive of its 14 compliance elements.  This butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained to meet or exceed the NFPA #58 requirements for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage.  



To date, this Facility has never had an accident involving the butane blending system resulting in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in-place.



In the event of an emergency involving the Nashville Terminal b

utane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Nashville Fire Department and request their assistance. The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Nashville Fire Department and the Davidson County LEPC.  The Nashville Fire Department, which maintains a full hazardous response team, is aware of the Facility's butane blending system, has access via Centennial Boulevard and 61st Avenue, and available fire suppression equipment including approximately twenty-four 20 lbs. ABC fire extinguishers, and water sources (nearest hydrant available at approximately 150 ft. distance from the vessel/off-loading point along 61st Avenue; additional units totaling three along the remainder of 61st Street and Centennial Boulevard).  Shell - Nashville Terminal maintains a vegetation control program to minimize plant growth within 10 ft. of the system.



Shell encourages employee input and is always striving to create the safest work environment possible. Shell ensures that the local responding agencies are kept up to date regarding terminal operations and actively seeks their participation in response drills.
